inscription:
山下春江一鏡開，江回山轉隔蓬萊。舟行仿佛聞雞犬，時有桃花出峽來。乙丑仲冬為鄭叔賢甥清玩。毓湖張湘，時年六十有五。
Beneath the mountains a spring river flows in abundance like a mirror, the river winds and the mountains encircle, separating Penglai; 
The boat travels as though hearing the chickens and dogs, at times peach blossoms appear along the sides of the gorge. 
During the middle of winter of the year 1805 (?), I painted this for the 
pure pleasure of my cousin Zheng Shuxian. Zhang Xiang, called Yuhu, at the age of sixty-five.”
signed: Artist’s seal: Zhang Xiang 張湘
text: This painting illustrates a scene from Peach-Blossom Spring, a tale written by poet Tao Qian (365–428). It tells of a fisherman who encounters a small opening in a mountain from which flows a bubbling spring. Through the opening is a utopia where people live in harmony and happiness, a metaphor for a refuge from our tumultuous world. Zhang Xiang’s painting captures the fisherman mooring his boat, dwarfed by the vast, misty landscape before him. The stream winds through the mountains, and hidden dwellings appear beyond. Ominous bluffs of rock frame the scene, conveying the untouchable nature of this idyllic realm.
title: Peach-Blossom Spring
